I'd be extremely wary of any code that uses operator overloading. It seems like a very bad idea to me, but YMMV.

Sorry, I'm not sure I understand what you mean by "operator overloading". Would you care to elaborate?

Overloading in C is usually used to define different behaviors for the same code, like the difference between (int) and (int *).
The problem with this in Python, is that all code is executed at compile time, not run-time, and so you can't just redefine operator+ to have a different behavior.

It doesn't define a different behavior for the same code. It defines a different code for the same behavior. It lets the user define a set of functions that can be used to do algebra.

So, what is it?

It's called a "Pythonic" solution. This is a tongue in cheek term, because Python (the language) is so easy to use and so flexible that it leads to "clever" solutions which are frequently quite messy to work with. It's a matter of style and taste.

Python, the language, is not easy to use. Python, the language, is easy to understand.

I think the problem is that most programmers would rather do _anything_ else than write Python. If they had a choice of any language, they'd go for something with an actual type system and a syntax that doesn't require so much white space.

This is a common theme in the way my code ends up looking. I do it for a few reasons:
1\. I'm lazy. I'd rather have a single, well-tested method do something than multiple well-tested methods. I figure it's easier to write one good method than it is to write a bunch of small ones.
2\. I'm not always sure what I'm doing, so I like to be able to test a small part of my code at a time.
3\. I can't decide which of a bunch of ideas is better, so I test them all.
4\. I'm not sure how to break it down into smaller parts.
5\. I don't think I'll ever need to change it, so I'll just leave it as is.
I hope you find something in my method that helps you.</s>

    if not operator:

    result = []
    while operand:
        result.append(operator[operand[1]], operand[1])

    result = result[0]*result[1] + result[1]*result[0]

    expression and return the evaluation of this expression.

       operand = [operand[0], operand[1], operand[2]]
